title: Tin whistle
data:
| ( [![Whistle.png](/images/1/18/Whistle.png)](/wiki/File:Whistle.png) |                                    |
| -------------------------------------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------- |
| Name                                                                 | tin whistle                        |
| Appearance                                                           | [whistle](/wiki/Whistle "Whistle") |
| Base price                                                           | 10 [zm](/wiki/Zorkmid "Zorkmid")   |
| Weight                                                               | [3](/wiki/Weight "Weight")         |
| Material                                                             | [metal](/wiki/Metal "Metal")       |
| Monster use                                                          | *Will not be used by monsters.*    |

A **tin whistle** is a type of [tool](/wiki/Tool "Tool") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. It is a non-magical, non-[tonal instrument](/wiki/Tonal_instrument "Tonal instrument") made of [metal](/wiki/Metal "Metal"), and appears as a [whistle](/wiki/Whistle "Whistle") when unidentified.

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Description](#Description)
  - [2.1 Range](#Range)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)

- [4 History](#History)

- [5 Origin](#Origin)

- [6 Messages](#Messages)

- [7 Variants](#Variants)

  - [7.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [7.2 UnNetHack](#UnNetHack)
  - [7.3 Hack'EM](#Hack.27EM)

- [8 References](#References)

## Generation

In addition to random generation, tool [shops](/wiki/Shop "Shop") will often have tin whistles.

[Watchmen](/wiki/Watchmen "Watchmen") have a 2⁄3 chance of [being generated with](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory") a tin whistle.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1) [Vault](/wiki/Vault "Vault") [guards](/wiki/Guards "Guards") will always generate with cursed tin whistles, providing a source for the shrill whistling sound a player will hear while escaping them (see the section on [messages](#Messages) below).[\[2\]](#cite_note-2)

## Description

[Applying](/wiki/Apply "Apply") a tin whistle of any [beatitude](/wiki/Beatitude "Beatitude") can wake nearby monsters from [sleep](/wiki/Sleep "Sleep"), and if your [pet](/wiki/Pet "Pet") is close enough to hear the noise, then for the next five turns it will try to approach you more closely.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3) [\[4\]](#cite_note-4)[\[5\]](#cite_note-5) Additionally, using a cursed tin whistle in a vault will immediately summon a guard.[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)

### Range

The range of a tin whistle is sqrt([xlvl](/wiki/Experience_level "Experience level")\*20), which in practice is half the range of a [leather drum](/wiki/Leather_drum "Leather drum").[\[7\]](#cite_note-7) This results in a radius of about 4 squares at XL 1, 16 squares at XL 14, and a maximum of 24 squares at XL 30.

## Strategy

The tin whistle is incredibly easy to identify: In addition to the above means of generation, you can apply any unidentified whistle - if you produce a strange or humming noise, then you have a [magic whistle](/wiki/Magic_whistle "Magic whistle"), and your pet appearing next to you will [auto-identify](/wiki/Auto-identify "Auto-identify") that whistle. See the messages below for further reference.

The best use of tin whistles is for attracting pets by applying one repeatedly until they come to you; this can sometimes help you take pets through stairs or out of [shops](/wiki/Shop "Shop"). Once you find a magic whistle, you can safely stash the tin whistle elsewhere. [Knights](/wiki/Knight "Knight") can also apply tin whistles to wake sleeping monsters before attacking them in order to avoid scaring them and violating their code of conduct - for most other situations where you wish to wake monsters, instruments such as [bugles](/wiki/Bugle "Bugle") are superior choices.

## History

The tin whistle first appears in [Hack 1.0](/wiki/Hack_1.0 "Hack 1.0"), where it is simply known as a whistle.

The effect of cursed tin whistles in vaults is introduced in [NetHack 3.6.1](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.1 "NetHack 3.6.1") - [NetHack 3.6.2](/wiki/NetHack_3.6.2 "NetHack 3.6.2") gives the vault guards their own cursed whistles.

## Origin

[![Wikipedia](/images/thumb/f/f8/Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png/50px-Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png)](/wiki/File:Fair-use-wikipedia-logo.png "Wikipedia")

[Wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Main_Page "wikipedia:Main Page") has an article about:

***[Tin whistle](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tin_whistle "wikipedia:Tin whistle")***

A tin whistle, or penny whistle, is a simple six-holed woodwind instrument. It is a type of [fipple](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fipple "wikipedia:Fipple") flute, named for the duct that directs air across an opening toward a sharp edge when blown into; the flute plays notes in a single key with a range of two octaves. Most 'tin' whistles are usually made of nickel-plated brass, and can even be made from wood or plastic. The tin whistle is closely associated with Irish traditional music and Celtic music.

The "tin whistle" of *NetHack* is more of a ['pea' whistle](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Whistle "wikipedia:Whistle"), as indicated by its [tile](/wiki/Tileset "Tileset") and characteristics: this is a very small type of whistle containing a pea (or similar object) to make its sound discordant. Pea whistles produce a single sound and are generally used to gain people's attention; they are commonly associated with sports referees and British policemen.

## Messages

- You produce a high whistling sound.

  You applied a non-cursed or blessed tin whistle.

- You produce a shrill whistling sound.

  You applied a cursed tin whistle.

- You feel rushing air tickle your nose.

  You applied a tin whistle while [deaf](/wiki/Deaf "Deaf").

- You hear the shrill sound of a guard's whistle.

  You fled from a guard without dropping your carried gold, and they blew the whistle in their inventory.

## Variants

In variants using an [object materials](/wiki/Object_materials "Object materials") system, the tin whistle can be made of varying materials, and the base item is referred to as a **pea whistle**.

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), you can [upgrade](/wiki/Upgrade "Upgrade") tin whistles into magic whistles and vice versa, making them far more useful in general - upgrading also does not break any [conducts](/wiki/Conduct "Conduct").

### UnNetHack

In [UnNetHack](/wiki/UnNetHack "UnNetHack"), both types of whistle are easier to differentiate, as each will auto-identify upon applying one.

### Hack'EM

In [Hack'EM](/wiki/Hack%27EM "Hack'EM"), applying a pea whistle will auto-identify it, as in UnNetHack.

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 655](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L655)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 658](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/makemon.c#L658)
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/apply.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 468](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/apply.c#L468)
4. [↑](#cite_ref-4) [src/dogmove.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 920](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/dogmove.c#L920)
5. [↑](#cite_ref-5) [src/dogmove.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 564](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/dogmove.c#L564)
6. [↑](#cite_ref-6) [src/apply.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 469](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/apply.c#L469)
7. [↑](#cite_ref-7) [src/mon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 3048](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mon.c#L3048)

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")

Tin whistle

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
(
Name tin whistle
Appearance whistle
Base price 10 zm
Weight 3
Material metal
Monster use Will not be used by monsters.

A tin whistle is a type of tool that appears in NetHack. It is a non-magical, non-tonal instrument made of metal, and appears as a whistle when unidentified.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Description
    • 2.1 Range
  • 3 Strategy
  • 4 History
  • 5 Origin
  • 6 Messages
  • 7 Variants
    • 7.1 SLASH'EM
    • 7.2 UnNetHack
    • 7.3 Hack'EM
  • 8 References

Generation

In addition to random generation, tool shops will often have tin whistles.

Watchmen have a 2⁄3 chance of being generated with a tin whistle.[1] Vault guards will always generate with cursed tin whistles, providing a source for the shrill whistling sound a player will hear while escaping them (see the section on messages below).[2]

Description

Applying a tin whistle of any beatitude can wake nearby monsters from sleep, and if your pet is close enough to hear the noise, then for the next five turns it will try to approach you more closely.[3] [4][5] Additionally, using a cursed tin whistle in a vault will immediately summon a guard.[6]

Range

The range of a tin whistle is sqrt(xlvl*20), which in practice is half the range of a leather drum.[7] This results in a radius of about 4 squares at XL 1, 16 squares at XL 14, and a maximum of 24 squares at XL 30.

Strategy

The tin whistle is incredibly easy to identify: In addition to the above means of generation, you can apply any unidentified whistle - if you produce a strange or humming noise, then you have a magic whistle, and your pet appearing next to you will auto-identify that whistle. See the messages below for further reference.

The best use of tin whistles is for attracting pets by applying one repeatedly until they come to you; this can sometimes help you take pets through stairs or out of shops. Once you find a magic whistle, you can safely stash the tin whistle elsewhere. Knights can also apply tin whistles to wake sleeping monsters before attacking them in order to avoid scaring them and violating their code of conduct - for most other situations where you wish to wake monsters, instruments such as bugles are superior choices.

History

The tin whistle first appears in Hack 1.0, where it is simply known as a whistle.

The effect of cursed tin whistles in vaults is introduced in NetHack 3.6.1 - NetHack 3.6.2 gives the vault guards their own cursed whistles.

Origin

Wikipedia has an article about:
Tin whistle

A tin whistle, or penny whistle, is a simple six-holed woodwind instrument. It is a type of fipple flute, named for the duct that directs air across an opening toward a sharp edge when blown into; the flute plays notes in a single key with a range of two octaves. Most 'tin' whistles are usually made of nickel-plated brass, and can even be made from wood or plastic. The tin whistle is closely associated with Irish traditional music and Celtic music.

The "tin whistle" of NetHack is more of a 'pea' whistle, as indicated by its tile and characteristics: this is a very small type of whistle containing a pea (or similar object) to make its sound discordant. Pea whistles produce a single sound and are generally used to gain people's attention; they are commonly associated with sports referees and British policemen.

Messages

You produce a high whistling sound.
You applied a non-cursed or blessed tin whistle.
You produce a shrill whistling sound.
You applied a cursed tin whistle.
You feel rushing air tickle your nose.
You applied a tin whistle while deaf.
You hear the shrill sound of a guard's whistle.
You fled from a guard without dropping your carried gold, and they blew the whistle in their inventory.

Variants

In variants using an object materials system, the tin whistle can be made of varying materials, and the base item is referred to as a pea whistle.

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, you can upgrade tin whistles into magic whistles and vice versa, making them far more useful in general - upgrading also does not break any conducts.

UnNetHack

In UnNetHack, both types of whistle are easier to differentiate, as each will auto-identify upon applying one.

Hack'EM

In Hack'EM, applying a pea whistle will auto-identify it, as in UnNetHack.

References

  1. ↑ src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 655
  2. ↑ src/makemon.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 658
  3. ↑ src/apply.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 468
  4. ↑ src/dogmove.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 920
  5. ↑ src/dogmove.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 564
  6. ↑ src/apply.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 469

A '''tin whistle''' is a type of [[tool]] that appears in ''[[NetHack]]''. It is a non-magical, non-[[tonal instrument]] made of [[metal]], and appears as a [[whistle]] when unidentified.

==Generation==
In addition to random generation, tool [[shop]]s will often have tin whistles.

[[Watchmen]] have a {{frac|2|3}} chance of [[Monster starting inventory|being generated with]] a tin whistle.{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|655|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} [[Vault]] [[guards]] will always generate with cursed tin whistles, providing a source for the shrill whistling sound a player will hear while escaping them (see the section on [[#Messages|messages]] below).{{refsrc|src/makemon.c|658|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

==Description==
[[Apply]]ing a tin whistle of any [[beatitude]] can wake nearby monsters from [[sleep]], and if your [[pet]] is close enough to hear the noise, then for the next five turns it will try to approach you more closely.{{refsrc|src/apply.c|468|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} {{refsrc|src/dogmove.c|920|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}{{refsrc|src/dogmove.c|564|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} Additionally, using a cursed tin whistle in a vault will immediately summon a guard.{{refsrc|src/apply.c|469|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}

===Range===
The range of a tin whistle is sqrt([[Experience_level|xlvl]]*20), which in practice is half the range of a [[leather drum]].{{refsrc|src/mon.c|3048|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} This results in a radius of about 4 squares at XL 1, 16 squares at XL 14, and a maximum of 24 squares at XL 30.

==Strategy==
The tin whistle is incredibly easy to identify: In addition to the above means of generation, you can apply any unidentified whistle - if you produce a strange or humming noise, then you have a [[magic whistle]], and your pet appearing next to you will [[auto-identify]] that whistle. See the messages below for further reference.

The best use of tin whistles is for attracting pets by applying one repeatedly until they come to you; this can sometimes help you take pets through stairs or out of [[shop]]s. Once you find a magic whistle, you can safely stash the tin whistle elsewhere. [[Knight]]s can also apply tin whistles to wake sleeping monsters before attacking them in order to avoid scaring them and violating their code of conduct - for most other situations where you wish to wake monsters, instruments such as [[bugle]]s are superior choices.

==History==
The tin whistle first appears in [[Hack 1.0]], where it is simply known as a whistle.

The effect of cursed tin whistles in vaults is introduced in [[NetHack 3.6.1]] - [[NetHack 3.6.2]] gives the vault guards their own cursed whistles.

==Origin==
{{wikipedia|Tin whistle}}
A tin whistle, or penny whistle, is a simple six-holed woodwind instrument. It is a type of [[wikipedia:Fipple|fipple]] flute, named for the duct that directs air across an opening toward a sharp edge when blown into; the flute plays notes in a single key with a range of two octaves. Most 'tin' whistles are usually made of nickel-plated brass, and can even be made from wood or plastic. The tin whistle is closely associated with Irish traditional music and Celtic music.

The "tin whistle" of ''NetHack'' is more of a [[wikipedia:Whistle|'pea' whistle]], as indicated by its [[Tileset|tile]] and characteristics: this is a very small type of whistle containing a pea (or similar object) to make its sound discordant. Pea whistles produce a single sound and are generally used to gain people's attention; they are commonly associated with sports referees and British policemen.

==Messages==
{{message|You produce a high whistling sound.|You applied a non-cursed or blessed tin whistle.}}
{{message|You produce a shrill whistling sound.|You applied a cursed tin whistle.}}
{{message|You feel rushing air tickle your nose.|You applied a tin whistle while [[deaf]].}}
{{message|You hear the shrill sound of a guard's whistle.|You fled from a guard without dropping your carried gold, and they blew the whistle in their inventory.}}

==Variants==
In variants using an [[object materials]] system, the tin whistle can be made of varying materials, and the base item is referred to as a '''pea whistle'''.

===SLASH'EM===
In [[SLASH'EM]], you can [[upgrade]] tin whistles into magic whistles and vice versa, making them far more useful in general - upgrading also does not break any [[conduct]]s.

===UnNetHack===
In [[UnNetHack]], both types of whistle are easier to differentiate, as each will auto-identify upon applying one.

===Hack'EM===
In [[Hack'EM]], applying a pea whistle will auto-identify it, as in UnNetHack.
